abstract: News outlets are preparing for a televised trial in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin, how Amazon benefits from the lawsuit over e-book prices, and a profile of Andrew Breitbart, the conservative provocateur who was “jacked into the Web early and never unplugged.”
snippet: News outlets are preparing for a televised trial in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin, how Amazon benefits from the lawsuit over e-book prices, and a profile of Andrew Breitbart, the conservative provocateur who was “jacked into the Web early a...
lead_paragraph: The shooting death of Trayvon Martin has transfixed social networks and news coverage, and that’s before there was an arrest. Now that George Zimmerman has been charged with second-degree murder in the shooting, news outlets are preparing for a televised trial that could receive blanket coverage on television networks and Web sites, Brian Stelter writes. “It has the potential to be as big as the O. J. Simpson trial — and just as divisive,” said Piers Morgan, the CNN interviewer.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: Planning for Zimmerman Trial, and What Breitbart Wrought

abstract: Magazine insert ads, with a scent, serve as teasers for the second season of “The Borgias.”
snippet: Magazine insert ads, with a scent, serve as teasers for the second season of “The Borgias.”
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline.main: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
headline.print_headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
